title: Hudson starts, Affeldt relieves as Giants have retirement party on mound
text:
Hudson starts, Affeldt relieves as Giants have retirement party on mound By Andrew Baggarly Posted: 10/01/2015 03:29:08 PM PDT Updated: 10/01/2015 03:43:36 PM PDT SAN FRANCISCO -- Tim Hudson, all of 40 years old and in his last major league appearance Thursday afternoon, painted a fastball for a third strike against hyped Dodgers rookie Corey Seager. 
The grand game goes on and on. Only the names change. 
Seager will be around a long time. If he's lucky, he'll get 17 seasons in the big leagues, find his way to a World Series ring and a standing ovation on his way out the door. Howie Kendrick might have whistled the last pitch of Hudson's career into center field for a single, but that did not dampen the applause as he doffed his cap to a standing ovation in the third inning of the Giants' 3-2 loss to the Dodgers at AT&T Park. SAN FRANCISCO, CA - OCTOBER 01: Tim Hudson #17 of the San Francisco Giants waves to the crowd after being taken out of the game in the third inning of their game against the Los Angeles Dodgers in the first inning at AT&T Park on October 1, 2015 in San Francisco, California. (Photo by Ezra Shaw/Getty Images) ( Ezra Shaw ) 
Jeremy Affeldt, the three-time World Series champion who announced his own retirement earlier in the day, followed Hudson on the mound and warmed up amid an emotional storm. The Giants lined up on the field near the dugout and formed a hug line for Hudson, whose bald head glistened in the sunshine. He retires with 222 victories, the most among active pitchers. 
By the time the book closed on his career, Hudson allowed three runs in 2﻿1/3 innings. He entered with a 3.49 ERA. Thursday's events didn't change it. 
Ryan Vogelsong, who most certainly is not retiring, displayed crisp stuff in what might have been his final appearance as a Giant. An impending free agent who could find his way back as a long reliever next season, Vogelsong allowed just one hit in four innings, struck out six and did not walk a batter. Advertisement 
The Giants didn't score until the eighth, when Angel Pagan hit an RBI single off the leg of left-hander Brett Anderson and then raced around the bases on Kelby Tomlinson's double. 
Marlon Byrd received four plate appearances and is 11 away from vesting an $8 million option for next season, but he's only expected to start perhaps one of the Giants' three remaining games. 
Matt Duffy went 0 for 4 to drop from .300 to .298 on the season. SAN FRANCISCO, CA - OCTOBER 01: Howie Kendrick #47 of the Los Angeles Dodgers slides safely past the tag of Trevor Brown #56 of the San Francisco Giants to score on fielders choice hit by Andre Ethier #16 of the Los Angeles Dodgers in the third inning at AT&T Park on October 1, 2015 in San Francisco, California. (Photo by Ezra Shaw/Getty Images) ( Ezra Shaw ) 
The Giants will hold pregame ceremonies over the weekend to honor Hudson and Affeldt. They will fete Hudson at 12:45 p.m. on Saturday; they will send off Affeldt at 11:30 a.m. Sunday. 
Madison Bumgarner will not start Sunday's season finale, Giants manager Bruce Bochy said. Bumgarner went 18-9 with a 2.93 ERA in 32 starts while pitching 218﻿1/3 innings — one more inning than his previous regular-season career high last year. Of course, Bumgarner threw 270 innings between the regular season and postseason last year. 
"He's good with it," Bochy said. "He's done enough." 
Yusmeiro Petit could start in Bumgarner's place unless he's needed earlier, Bochy said. 
Bochy followed a heartfelt tribute to Affeldt by saying, "I'm certainly going to miss those beautiful scuds he threw." The manager also asked media members for a synopsis of Affeldt's farewell news conference. "I didn't get a chance to listen. Did he talk about his hitting?"
